Inside a moving car at night, a medium interior shot shows two men in the front seats as the vehicle drives fast but steadily down a dark road, streetlights streaking softly across the windshield. The younger man with long black hair grips the steering wheel, nodding to the beat and confidently singing along to upbeat 1980s Europop music, clearly lip-syncing the lyrics “Cheri, cheri lady, goin’ through a motion, love is where you find it,” his mouth movements matching the rhythm. The camera gently vibrates with the car’s motion while staying stable and realistic, maintaining smooth continuity. Beside him, an older man with gray hair and a tense face grows visibly irritated, his jaw clenched and brow furrowed as he turns toward the driver. He suddenly shouts angrily, “Stop singing this shit!” and sharply slaps the younger man across the face, the action quick but believable, with a brief pause afterward as the music continues faintly. The camera holds on their reactions, capturing the awkward silence and lingering tension inside the speeding car, with engine noise and muffled music playing under the dialogue.
